abstract: steinhoff faces a firesale , but is set for a fizzle .
article: with the crisis deepening at steinhoff international holdings nv , a january sale of its assets looks increasingly likely . but this is not the time to be offloading retail businesses . the company was putting a brave face on its operating performance at a presentation to creditors on tuesday . that does not alter the fact that for some of its large assets , buyers are unlikely to be queuing up . and it 's not just because of risks stemming from the increasing loss of lines of credit . cut price . steinhoff 's share price sank again on poor news coming out of tuesday 's creditor meeting .

take conforama , the french furniture retailer . steinhoff said it experienced a 1 percent fall in core like-for-like sales in the year to september , although they turned positive in october and november . the company faces serious competition that extends beyond amazon . com inc. . local rival fnac darty sa is already muscular , and could get stronger . its former chief executive officer , alexandre bompard , now runs supermarket carrefour sa , raising the prospect the two groups could combine -- they 've already teamed up to buy consumer electronics in france . then there 's mattress firm in the u. s. steinhoff paid handsomely for this business in 2016 , and it has since struggled .

steinhoff did n't disclose detailed trading figures on tuesday , but did say it needed another $ 200 million to continue restructuring the business in 2018 . any buyer would have to fund this . steinhoff 's geographic split . europe was the biggest source of steinhoff 's revenue last year . the other european assets are a mixed bag . pepco , the eastern european variety retailer , could be attractive -- like-for-like sales expanded 20 percent in the year to september . steinhoff said poundland , the u. k. discount retailer it bought last july , had increased like-for-like sales by 4 percent in the current financial year .

but the chain faces competition from rival b&m european value retail sa , and food retailers . it 's also particularly exposed to the worries on credit availability . conditions are not ideal for a sale of its u. k. furniture retailers , bensons for beds and harveys furniture . some of their competition , feather & black and multiyork , recently fell into administration . big-ticket items have been a casualty of britons ' incomes being squeezed by inflation . christo wiese , steinhoff 's largest shareholder and until recently its chairman , also backs investment vehicle brait se .

that owns new look in the u. k. , and a majority stake in iceland foods . brait has n't been affected by the problems at steinhoff so far , and there 's no guarantee that there will be any knock-on effects . but with wiese having a 35 percent stake , it ca n't be ruled out . if there were to be any shake-up here , brait 's european retail assets are yet another diverse assortment for would-be buyers to consider . as my bloomberg colleague sam chambers has noted , new look faces a crucial christmas , after sales and profits have slumped .

brait also owns 60 percent of iceland foods . the frozen food retailer has revitalized its trading after suffering at the hands of the german cut price supermarkets . there would likely be willing acquirers too . founder malcolm walker led a buy-out of the chain in 2012 , and continues to have control over the business . he and his family could up their stakes again . with supermarket consolidation back in fashion , trade or private equity buyers might also be interested . wm morrison supermarkets plc looked at iceland five years ago , but ultimately did not make a move .

steinhoff 's debt . its most-liquid bond assumes deep losses for credit investors , and nothing for equity investors . while the share price reacted violently to the lack of progress tuesday with bank creditors , the bonds of steinhoff were less perturbed . but that is because they 're already assuming no value for shareholders . there will be some worth in steinhoff 's retail chains . but investors should n't get their hopes up that it will be much . to contact the author of this story : andrea felsted in london at afelsted@bloomberg . net .
